ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Console use detrimental?
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Congrats.  Whats it do? ... No error on your part. I m guessing what you re seeing is the construction of two instances? The console sets up a CrawlJob

bergmark_d wrote:

>
> I just wrote my first pluggable module and did a two-minute crawl with
> it, running the crawl from the console.  


Congrats.  Whats it do?

> I was very surprised to see
> that my module's constructor was called twice!  (This was seen via
> debugging prints to heritrix_out.log.)  Suspicious, I then reran the
> order file with the -n switch on heritrix.  Without the console, the
> constructor was called only once, as expected.
>
> Without looking at the .jsp's in any detail, it appears that each
> invocation of my module comes after a slightly different series of
> webapp events.  In Java-land, both invocations started from
> ThreadPool.java line 511 (in PoolThread.run).  The non-console run
> starts with Heritrix.main which calls doStart which calls
> doOneCrawl and is then off and running.
>
> Has anyone else observed this problem with the console?  Was it just
> operator error on my part?  


No error on your part.

I'm guessing what you're seeing is the construction of two instances?

The console sets up a CrawlJob instance for all jobs it knows of 
including past crawls found in the jobs directory.  The CrawlJob 
constructor calls the settings' handler initialize method using each 
found crawl jobs order file.  The settings' handler initialize is 
instantiating an instance of each module found in the order file -- an 
instance per crawl job.  This is the double-call to the constructor I'm 
guessing you're seeing.  Oh, the console also sets up at least the 
default profile, which is nought but a CrawlJob in another guise -- 
which probably explains the dbl-construction call in a new instance.

Someday figure a more lightweight CrawlJob representation -- especially 
for old jobs.

St.Ack

>
>
> It can be dangerous to have your constructor called twice, since you
> might want to do some one-time I/O, for example.  Since the problem
> can be worked around, it is not too serious, but I was curious.
>
> Regards, D.
>
>
